Comment: Hey everyone! This is a tournament game I played recently. The opponent resigned prematurely, but I was wondering if the experts could comment on my mistakes.
He he plays the bc4. I looked at the opponents history and he seems to favor the 4 move checkmate.
He he plays the bc4. I looked at the opponents history and he seems to favor the 4 move checkmate.
In preparation for this, I start to develop my pieces slowly.
As I said, he pulled out his Queen, and i have to block the 4 move checkmate.
This is the usual preventative measure against the 4 move. If anyone uses a different method, just let me know. I like this method because it also develops pieces, but I'm open to suggestion.
I think he intends to challenge my knight with the bishop, but I don't see what damage that could do.
But since it was a tournament game, I decided to take preventative measures. I played h6 to block that attack.
Here he obviously intends to castle, which gives me 2 free moves to begin to develop and build an attack.
This is not intended to be an amateur move, but I like the position of Bc5. It takes control of the middle of the board, and also attacks a weak position in white's line of pawns.
I assume this move has a duel purpose: It blocks the advance of the knight, while also preventing the checkmate of the King behind three pawns later in the game.
Now that I am certain he will castle on this side, I decide to focus my attack on the Kingside pawns.
I looked at his profile, and he also favors playing Bh6. This movement of the Queen prepares that move, because the pawn is now pinned.
Here is where I throw him a line, hoping he would take it. In the next few moves I will gain a significant advantage because of a move that appears to be a mistake.
It appears as if I just gave him a pawn, but he actually fell into a trap. I can now play Qa5+.
This was his last chance to prevent the loss of his Queen. Had he moved his King instead, he would have prevented a check with Bxf2+.
This was his last chance to prevent the loss of his Queen. Had he moved his King instead, he would have prevented a check with Bxf2+.
Now he is in check, and his Queen is exposed, unprotected. His main option is Kxf2. I can now capture his queen and gain a significant advantage.
At this point I thought I had it locked up, but it turned out differently than I expected.
At this point I thought I had it locked up, but it turned out differently than I expected.
He is blocking Qxb2, which would expose his rook, although he could have played bc3 in response, with his bishop protected, but that was his choice.
The last two moves were unimportant, just building a position on either side. I have now challenged his bishop, forcing him to retreat. His only option is Bb3.
The last two moves were unimportant, just building a position on either side. I have now challenged his bishop, forcing him to retreat. His only option is Bb3.
The last two moves were unimportant, just building a position on either side. I have now challenged his bishop, forcing him to retreat. His only option is Bb3.
I can now prevent him from taking pieces with his e4 pawn, because I have mated the rook and Queen. I later decide to capitalize on this weakness in his defense.
I can now prevent him from taking pieces with his e4 pawn, because I have mated the rook and Queen. I later decide to capitalize on this weakness in his defense.
